titlestmt.titleproper: Crossing Borders, Bridging Generations Mixed Heritage Oral History Project 2011.019
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Margaret Fraser

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-10-07T17:11-0400

did.unittitle: Crossing Borders, Bridging Generations Mixed Heritage Oral History Collection
did.abstract: This collection is a part of Crossing Borders, Bridging Generations (CBBG), an oral history project and public programming series, examines the history and experiences of mixed-heritage people and families, cultural hybridity, race, ethnicity, and identity in the historically diverse borough of Brooklyn. The oral history interview collection began in October 2011 by a team of 25 interviewers and is ongoing.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Brooklyn Historical Society (Brooklyn, New York, N.Y.).

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Forty-five years ago, interracially married couples faced prosecution and jail time, or violence, if they happened to cross into one of sixteen states that prohibited and punished marriages on the basis of racial classifications . Sixty years ago, anti-miscegenation laws were on the books in thirty states. Eighty-two years ago, in 1930, the Hays Code forbade portrayals of interracial romance, curtailing the careers of actors of color like Anna May Wong who could no longer play romantic leads. In Germany in 1935, The Nuremberg Laws were introduced that prohibited marriage between Jewish Germans and other Germans. The only other nation to legislate against intermarriage was Apartheid South Africa in 1949. While interfaith marriages were not legally proscribed in the United States, interfaith and interclass marriages often met with opposition from family and community. And yet, in less than two generations since the last anti-miscegenation laws were removed, a study released by the Pew Research Center in 2010 reports that a record one out of seven new marriages in the United States were between spouses of a different race or ethnicity. The 2010 U.S. Census revealed that multiracial and multiethnic children are one of the country’s fastest-growing demographic groups.

The Crossing Borders, Bridging Generations Project aims to explore these historical ideas through modern day interviews with multiple generations of Brooklynites. It is an oral history project and public programming series which examines the history and experiences of mixed-heritage people and families, cultural hybridity, race, ethnicity, and identity in the historically diverse borough of Brooklyn. Through sharing stories, we open up intergenerational conversations about preserving cultural heritage in a multicultural democracy. Narrators came to this project through connections with the project the interviewing team and CBBG public programs.

Crossing Borders, Bridging Generations is a project of the Brooklyn Historical Society which builds upon BHS's oral history collections. Begun in 1973, the oral history collections contain interviews with more than 500 narrators and are available for listening in the Othmer Library. Crossing Borders, Bridging Generations is an ongoing project that is funded by the National Endowment for the Humanities, the Institute for Museum and Library Services, and New York Council for the Humanities.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Narrator’s Name, Oral history interview, YYYY, Crossing Borders Bridging Generations Oral History Collection, Catalog Number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: These oral history interviews are intimate conversations between two people, both of whom have generously agreed to share these recordings with the Brooklyn Historical Society archives, and with you. Please listen in the spirit with which these were shared.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The interviews in this collection are about mixed heritage identity and the borough of Brooklyn. For the purposes of this project, the definition of mixed was kept open and fluid, allowing narrators to have the space to describe themselves in their own words. Thought all interviewers took a life history approach to these interviews, they were collected by a team of over 25 interviewers and the content reflects different styles of interviewing and differing levels of famliarity between the interviewer and narrator.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged by each interviews accession number which was given at the time the interview came to the Brooklyn Historical Society.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials Note
relatedmaterial.p: Please see the Crossing Borders, Bridging Generations website cbbg.brooklynhistory.org for related resources and project news.

processinfo.head: Processing Information Note
processinfo.p: This finding aid will be updated regularly as new interviews continue.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This interview is hereby made available for research purposes only.
All rights are reserved by the Brooklyn Historical Society, Brooklyn, New York.

1. The Brooklyn Historical Society abides by the General Principles & Best Practices for Oral History as agreed upon by the Oral History Association (2009) and expects that use of this material will be done with respect for these professional ethics.

2. This transcript is a nearly verbatim copy of the recorded interview. As such, it may contain the natural false starts, verbal stumbles, misspeaks, and repetitions that are common in conversation. This decision was made because BHS gives primacy to the audible voice and also because some researchers do find useful information in these verbal patterns.

3. Unless these verbal patterns are germane to your scholarly work, when quoting from this material researchers are encouraged to correct the grammar and make other modifications maintaining the flavor of the narrator’s speech while editing the material for the standards of print.

did.unittitle: Shawn Elgart 2011.019.001

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Shawn Elgart is an African American woman who lives in Brooklyn with her husband and their daughter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this interview, Shawn Elgart discusses her interracial marriage and family.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

did.unittitle: Oral History Interview (audio) with Shawn Elgart
Oral History Interview (transcript) with Shawn Elgart
Teresa Ish 2011.019.002

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: During this interview, Ish offers a detailed account of what it was like to be raised by an interracial couple and how her life has been influenced by her mixed-heritage. She talks about celebrating the Chinese New Year and her Grandmother’s hybrid Chinese-American versions of traditional Chinese dishes, such as peanut butter bao. In addition to her own memories, Ish recalled stories of her Grandmother and Great Grandmother in Malaysia. In the interview, she reflects on what it was like to physically appear culturally ambiguous and how, as an avid traveler, this has given her an advantage as she can blend in almost anywhere in the world. She elaborates on these types of positive aspects of having a mixed-heritage, but also voices frustrations about racial prejudices towards Chinese culture in America. Ish also speaks about the experience of raising her daughter in Brooklyn and contemplates what her life will be like and how she will be perceived.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Teresa Ish grew up in Fresno, California and is of Chinese-Malaysian and Swedish descent. She attended UC Santa Cruz for both her undergraduate and graduate studies. Ish studied Marine Biology and co-founded FishWise, a nonprofit consultancy that promotes seafood sustainability. She met her husband in college and now lives in Brooklyn with her husband and daughter.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction.

did.unittitle: Itamar Goldstein 2011.019.004

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Itamar Goldstein is a 28-year-old medical student, born in Jeruslaem, Israel in 1983. His mother is a Yemenite Jew and his father is an American Jew. He came to the U.S. for undergrad at Columbia and moved to SUNY Downstate to study medicine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Goldstein talks about living with “roots across the ocean,” roots both in Israrel and in New York City. He talks about growing up in a mixed community, where everyone was a mix—part Moroccan and part American, etc. He talks about his first experiences in the U.S. at 10, after his parents divorced. He reflects on the differences between Judaism in Israel and in the U.S. He relates what a small and intimate community he grew up in, among Yemenite Jews, and the mix of Arab and Hebrew that he grew up speaking. He talks about how people never know what he is, whether he’s Mexican or Arab or Mediterranean. He talks about the way things like the Israeli army, travel, and the decision to be a doctor shaped him.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction.

did.unittitle: Oral History Interview (audio) with Itamar Goldstein
Oral History Interview (transcript) with Itamar Goldstein
Madeleine Kanai 2011.019.005

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Madeleine Kanai grew up in Kobe, Japan and Lexington, Kentucky. Her father is also of mixed heritage (Japanese and American) and her mother is from Kentucky. Kanai lived in Brooklyn, New York for a period of time before moving into Manhattan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In her interview, Kanai explores her Japanese heritage. She speaks Japanese as her first language but remembers being treated poorly when she lived in Japan. In one instance, she visited Hiroshima with her mother and overheard people talking about them in Japanese. She moved to Lexington, Kentucky when she was eight years old. Kanai has a very strong connection to her own family history and is able to trace her family back through many generations.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction.

did.unittitle: Oral History Interview (audio) with Madeleine Kanai
Oral History Interview (transcript) with Madeleine Kanai
Harry Schwartzman 2011.019.006

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Harry Schwartzman’s mother is Japanese and his father is Jewish. He grew up speaking Japanese, Yiddish and English. Schwartzman is from New York and has traveled and lived in many other places. He currently calls Brooklyn home.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In his interview, Schwartzman talks about growing up speaking Japanese and Yiddish. He did not start speaking English until he attended nursery school. He has a deep connection to New York, and noticed differences between the way people reacted to him and his brother on their frequent visits to Japan.

did.unittitle: Daniela Caraballo 2011.019.007

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this interview, Caraballo discusses her Dominican and Puerto Rican heritage, her upbringing and education, and her decision to become a social worker.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Daniela Caraballo grew up in Sunset Park and Bensonhurst and is of Dominican and Puerto Rican descent. She currently lives in Brooklyn and is a social worker.

Lisa Heller 2011.019.008

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Lisa Hiller identifies as biracial (black and white) and grew up in the Bronx in a Jewish family. She currently lives in Brooklyn.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this interview, Heller discusses her upbringing in New York City and how her understanding of her biracial identity changed over time.

did.unittitle: Oral History Interview (audio) with Lisa Heller
Oral History Interview (transcript) with Lisa Heller
Katherine Ambia 2011.019.009

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Katherine Ambia grew up in Sunset Park, Brooklyn with her twin brother, her White-American mother and Peruvian father. She got her bachelor’s in Latin American studies from Wesleyan, her MSW from Columbia University, and is currently training as a clinician with the Yale Child Study Center's Intensive In-home Child and Adolescent Psychiatric Services program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this interview, Ambia discusses the way her racial identity has changed over time, from growing up in the culturally and economically mixed neighborhood of Sunset Park and attending a Quaker elementary school in Brooklyn Heights, to studying critical race theory formally as a young adult at Wesleyan University. Ambia elaborates on the cultural and economic backgrounds of her parents, who met as community organizers in the 1970s. She tells the story of her father’s childhood in a small indigenous village in Peru, his coming to the U.S., and his first experiences with American racism. She also tells the stories of her mother and maternal grandmother, an enterprising groundbreaker who worked in advertising in New York in the fifties, when the field was dominated by men.

She describes her parents as political organizers with a passion for worker and immigrant rights. Ambia remembers going to protests and growing up with those same values as a child. She also vividly accounts her personal experience of being mixed race, touching on the silence around the issue in her household, her trips to Peru to visit her father’s family, the messages she received from her maternal grandmother, as well as the racism she encountered in school from peers. As an adult, she reconciles her experience growing up mixed-race; how what she studied and whom she met in college has helped her develop a language around talking about her identity that she didn’t have as a child.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction.

did.unittitle: Asha Sundararaman 2011.019.010

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Sundararaman is a woman of Indian and white heritage who identifies as a third culture kid. Originally from California, she has lived in many other places including India, Indiana, London and Brooklyn. She currently works in an administrative capacity at a non-profit that provides international blindness prevention healthcare.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In her interivew, Sundararaman talks about her experiences being multiracial in difference places across the country and around the world. She felt the most at home in Angola, where she felt difference was understood and accepted and not scrutinized like in California or in Indiana. Diversity has been important in her friend groups and in her interview she discusses how race has played out in groups where she was the one or one of two people of color. She also talks about her parents’ relationship with each other and with their in-laws.

did.unittitle: Alexander David 2011.019.011

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: David is a sophomore at City College, enrolled as a Macaulay Honors student and majoring in biomedical engineering. He attended Stuyvesant High School where he played baseball and football. He identifies as mixed-heritage because his mother is of Chinese descent and his father is of Romanian descent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: During his interview, David discusses his many identities: mixed-heritage, a student, and an athlete. He describes his transition from Middle School to High School and the social and academic adjustments that they demanded of him. David’s mixed heritage identity has impacted him throughout his upbringing in Brooklyn and life as a student. He tells the story of how his parents became acquainted and discusses the effect of cultural-mixing on his self-perception and reception of others. He describes his motivations for founding a club for mixed-heritage students at Stuyvesant High School and enumerates the discussions that the students partook in during meetings, including how mothers would often mix dishes from two cultures to create their own hybrid recipes. He also talks about how his mixed identity plays out in other areas of his life. For example, unlike most pitchers in baseball, he also hits and does not play the field.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction.

did.unittitle: Julie Kline 2011.019.012

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Julie Kline is from Oakland California and grew up in a multi-faith family. She currently lives in Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this interview, Kline talks about her family and ancestry, growing up in California, and the many transitional periods in her life, including her move to Brooklyn.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

did.unittitle: Oral History Interview (audio) with Julie Kline
Oral History Interview (transcript) with Julie Kline
Katherine Ambia 2011.019.013

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Katherine Ambia grew up in Sunset Park, Brooklyn with her twin brother, her White-American mother and Peruvian father. She got her bachelor’s in Latin American studies from Wesleyan, her MSW from Columbia University, and is currently training as a clinician with the Yale Child Study Center's Intensive In-home Child and Adolescent Psychiatric Services program.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In Ambia’s second interview, she goes into more into detail about her childhood experiences. She talks about feeling isolated or bullied at times during her childhood, while also feeling a close connection to her friends on her block and at her Quaker school. She describes her experience of female friendship as a kid; including where and when race came into that dynamic. She shows us the inside of her childhood home: filled with elaborate games, toys, art projects, Disney movies, story writing, no television and a lot of health food. Ambia also talks about her interest in sports, cooking, and holistic health helped her connect with her father.

Ambia talks about the differing ideas of race within her own family and how her brother’s experience around these issues differs from her own. She also relates how her family would celebrate holidays with the two separate sides of her multiracial family, and she tells stories about the differing rituals. She goes on to talk about her parents’ separation in high school and what she has learned about relationships from watching her own family. She describes her own experiences of dating and her racial identity.

Ambia also focuses a lot on the effect her education has had on who she is today. She talks about teachers who’ve profoundly affected her both before and in college, exciting her interest in literature, race in society, social justice and her own cultural background. She tells us is in detail about her formative year abroad in Bolivia and more generally, about her broad and rich education at Wesleyan and the acceptance she found there. At the end of the interview, she talks about her choices around her profession. Ambia talks about how her commitment to social justice and equality contributed to her decision to become a therapist. She discusses some possible long-term goals such as building a psychiatric practice and expresses her enthusiasm for the CBBG project and the importance of this kind of work.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction.

did.unittitle: Lenge Hong 2011.019.014

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Lenge Hong is of Chinese and Scottish heritage and originally from Miami, Florida. She lived in the Clinton Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn while attending NYU. Lenge currently lives in Manhattan and works as a library cataloger with a collection of historic photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this interview, Hong talks about her experiences being multiracial at a time and in a place where it was largely misunderstood. She grew up in Miami, Florida where her father owned and operated a Chinese restaurant, of which she holds fond memories. Most people in Miami assumed she was Cuban or Native American. Most people did not think Hong was Asian and most of the Asians in the area were a part of her family. She also talks about having visited Hawaii which was one of the only times she has felt like she has totally blended in. She spends time reflecting on the difference in attitude and acceptance toward multiracial people in the 1970s and the present. Hong wonders how her life would have been different if she hadn't grown up with a Chinese name, which both her and her sister were given. She also talks about her experience answering the question "what are you?" which she got asked many times growing up. Her feelings and answers to this question have changed over her lifetime.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction.

did.unittitle: Sonnet Takahisa 2011.019.015

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Raised in Brooklyn by a Japanese father and a Jewish mother of Russian/Polish heritage, Sonnet Takahisa transforms her past and current multi-cultural family background into unique professional expertise that she applies in museums, art and cultural institutions and schools.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In her interview, Sonnet describes the Japanese family traditions of her father and the family traditions of her Jewish mother. She spends time reflecting on the experiences of different generations of her family with respect to ethnicity and identity perception. She talks about her upbringing in Brooklyn, especially her experiences with grade school, with college, and with her first jobs.

did.unittitle: Alicia Piller 2011.019.016

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Alicia Piller is an artist and jewelry designer living in Brooklyn, New York. Originally from Chicago, Illinois, her mother is African American and her father is Jewish and of Belgian and Polish descent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this interview, Piller discusses her upbringing in Chicago, her ancestry and multifaith family, her college experience, and her work as in artist in Brooklyn. She identifies as culturally Jewish.

Vilray Bolles 2011.019.017

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Vilray Bolles grew up in Park Slope, Brooklyn. His father is American and his mother is from Nicaragua. Bolles currently works as a musician.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In his interview, Bolles discusses his experience growing up and going to school in Brooklyn and at LaGuardia for jazz music. He also talks about his brother’s connection to Islam, memories of going to church with his family, his connection to music, and the immigrant experience.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

Fikre Workneh 2011.019.018

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Fikre Workneh is from Ethiopia and grew up in the Ethiopian Orthodox Church. Before marrying Clare Workneh, he worked as a chaplain and missionary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In his interview, Fikre discusses his upbringing in the Ethipoian Orthodox Church and his experience as a missionary and chaplain in the church. He talks about moving to the United States and serving the church in Harlem as well as his meeting and marriage to his wife Clare.

Clare and Fikre Workneh 2011.019.020

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Clare Workneh was born in Brooklyn and grew up in Queens, New York. She worked as a nun and later as a social worker. She married Fikre Workneh in 1974.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In her interview, Clare Workneh talks about her memories of the convent, her Irish background, her father converting to Catholicism when he met her mother and ethnic difference.

did.unittitle: Oral History Inteview (audio) with Clare and Fikre Workneh
Oral History Interview (transcript) with Clare and Fikre Workneh
Bette Yee 2011.019.021

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Bette Yee is of Chinese descent and was born in Boston, Massachusetts. Yee also grew up in New Hampshire, where her family had a restaurant called China Dragon Inn. Yee attended the University of New Hampshire and moved to Brooklyn in the 1980s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this interview, Yee talks about moving to New Hampshire from Boston and living with her uncle who was married to a French Canadian woman. She discusses what it was like to grow up between two worlds – between her Chinese family and American society. She also describes her experience with the civil rights movements, her marriage, moving to Brooklyn in the 1980s and her exposure to the Asian American feminist movement, and her family’s disapproval of her own wedding.

dao.ns2:title: Bette Yee

daodesc.p: Bette Yee, 1949-2012

did.unittitle: Jonathan Blazon 2011.019.022

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Jonathan Blazon was born in Manchester, New Hampshire. He is of Chinese, French-Canadian, and American Indian descent and identifies as Hapa. He lived in Brooklyn before and after spending ten years studying in France. Jonathan has a Master's degree in Fine Arts. His mother, Bette Yee, was also interviewed for this project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this interview, Blazon describes what it was like to grow up Hapa in New Hampshire. He talks about being bullied and never being seen as Chinese despite identifying more with his Chinese heritage than his French Canadian background. Blazon discusses life in his family’s restaurant in New Hampshire. He talks about living in France for ten years and what it was like to return to Brooklyn where he noticed significant changes in the attitude toward and understanding of mixed heritage people. He thinks about how his own feelings of being Hapa will affect his daughter.

did.unittitle: Vilray Bolles 2011.019.023

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Vilray Bolles grew up in Park Slope, Brooklyn. His father is American and his mother is from Nicaragua. Bolles currently works as a musician.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this interview Vilray Bolles describes his life in Brooklyn since he graduated from college and his views on gentrification in the neighborhood of Park Slope, in which he grew up in.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

Elizabeth Velazquez 2011.019.024

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Elizabeth Velazquez was raised in Sullivan County in upstate New York. As the daughter of two immigrants (a Puerto Rican father and a Peruvian mother), Velazquez feels connected to the students in her Art classes at PS 89, Cypress Hills Community School, which is a bilingual school predominantly comprised of students of Latin American backgrounds. Velazquez is dedicated to learning more about her background and her family history, which are themes that often arise in her personal art practice.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: During this interview, which was conducted in Velazquez's art studio, Velazquez discusses her ongoing quest for knowledge, what she refers to as a lost history, in order to feel a greater connection to the past. She discusses feeling lost and never fitting in, whether in the US, in Puerto Rico, or in Peru, while feeling connected to her students in Brooklyn, who come from similar backgrounds.

Growing up in upstate NY, Velazquez remembers looking around in her classes to identify someone else like her. She reflects on being raised Pentacostal, and feeling grateful for experiencing the food and music of other Latin American and Caribbean church members. She also discusses observing her father building and fixing things, which she later understood as a reflection of Puerto Rican history in her dad, who she views as an embodiment of where he grew up. As an adult, Velazquez seeks to fill the loss of ancestral knowledge, which she admits often results in anger mixed with a feeling of wanting to be at peace, which she compares to fighting a phantom.

did.unittitle: Mala and Sham Mosher 2011.019.025

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Mala is of Chinese and Burmese descent and grew up in New York City. Sham is from Washington, D.C.. His mother is black and his father is white and he grew up Sikh. Mala and Sham met in 1988 and their first apartment was in Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this interview, Mala and Sham Mosher talk about their own upbringings and their family ancestry. They talk about their relationship and how it was perceived by their own families.

Vanessa Snowden and Sebastien Fargeat 2011.019.026

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Vanessa Snowden’s mother hails from Venezuela and her father grew up in the US. Sebastien Fargeat is from Lyon, France originally. They met when Snowden was working as an au pair in France. She is currently a teacher in the New York City Schools; he leads sightseeing expeditions for French tourists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this interview, Snowden and Fargeat discusses their upbringings in Buffalo, NY and Lyon, France. Snowden talks about experiences in education growing up and as a teacher. Both talk about how they met and relate stories about their wedding and moving back to the US.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Alicia Piller is an artist and jewelry designer living in Brooklyn, New York. Originally from Chicago, Illinois, her mother is African American and her father is Jewish and of Belgian and Polish descent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In her second interview, Piller talks about her education and what it was like to live in Chicago, Illinois as compared to Brooklyn, New York with respect to her background and identity.

accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Justice Whitaker grew up in California. His mother is white and his father is black. He currently lives in Brooklyn and works as an artist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In his interview, Justice Whitaker talks about growing up in California, his encounters with racism, how his parents’ backgrounds influenced his life, and moving to New York City for college.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Melissa Jimenez is of Filipino and Dominican descent. She was very close with her grandmother from the Philippines.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In her interview, Melissa Jimenez talks about her upbringing in a mixed family and the challenges of having two families close by that spoke different languages. She also talks about going to Chinatown with her grandmother and her daughter.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Justice Whitaker grew up in California. His mother is white and his father is black. He currently lives in Brooklyn and works as an artist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Jessica Chen Drammeh grew up in West Virginia with her Taiwanese mother and white father. She grew up speaking Chinese and English. She has lived in many neighborhoods in Brooklyn and works as filmmaker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In her interview, Jessica Chen Drammeh talks about her relationship with her parents and extended family, her experience in school and her family’s language practices. She talks about moving to New York City for college and the influence of arts and music on her life, as well as her career as a filmmaker.

Lowell Pete Beveridge 2011.019.032

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers without restriction.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Lowell Pete Beveridge has lived in Brooklyn since 1954 and was born in Massachusetts. He studied history at Harvard and Columbia and later married an African American woman from Harlem. He was involved in many political activities throughout his life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In his interview he talks about his upbringing in New York and summers in Maine, his background in history, American politics and his wife.

Ari Joseph 2011.019.033

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Ari Joseph grew up in Park Slope, Brooklyn and attended LaGuardia High School of Music and Art where he studied music. His father is white and Jewish and his mother is Peruvian and Chinese.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In his interview, Ari Joseph talks about what Brooklyn means to him and how it has changed over time. He also talks about what being “international” means to him, his education, and his relationship to music and Judaism.

Hansraj Maharawal 2011.019.034

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Hansraj Maharawal grew up in Park Slope and Prospect Heights, Brooklyn and attended Sarah Lawrence College. He currently works as a production assistant on photo shoots and is an artist. His mother is from New Jersey and is Scottish and his father is from India.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In his interview, Maharawal is interviewed by his sister Mannissa McCleave Maharawal. In it, he talks about his friendships growing up in Brooklyn and what has changed about the borough since he was a child. He also talks about racism, whiteness, hipster culture, and the art world.

Shawnta Smith 2011.019.035

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Shawnta Smith was born and raised in East Flatbush, Brooklyn to a Jamaica-born father and a black mother whose parents were Gatemalan/Garifuna. She currently works as a librarian and archivist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In her interview, Shawnta Smith discusses growing up on “the sunny side of Brooklyn” a few blocks where she lives today. She talks about her education in an area where race and class differed greatly from place to place. She talks about her family structures, her values, and her work in queer organizing , activism, performance, and production.

Thomas Lax 2011.019.036

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Thomas Lax grew up on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, New York. His mother is African-American and French and his father is Jewish-American. Lax received his BA in Africana Studies at Brown University where he did a year abroad in Dakar, Senegal. He currently works as an exhibition coordinator and program associate and lives in Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In his interview, Thomas Lax tells stories about race and race relations, sexuality, religion and ethnicity that span generations and continents. He talks about how these stories relate to his own identity and how that identity has changed over time.

Joseph Figueroa 2011.019.037

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Joseph Figueroa is a native Brooklynite of Puerto Rican and descent. He currently works in the community with at risk youth.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In his interview, Joseph talks about growing up in Brownsville, Brooklyn, a predominately African American neighborhood in Brooklyn. He also explains his community work and how he is able to connect with and help youth today.

Daisy Dominguez 2011.019.038

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This interview is only available onsite at the Brooklyn Historical Society's Othmer Library. Please contact the library before your visit regarding access to this interview. For information about visiting the library, please see http://www.brooklynhistory.org/library/visit.html.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Daisy Dominguez is a first generation Ecuadorian-American who lived in Brooklyn for part of her childhood. She is a librarian at City College and has now returned to Brooklyn.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this interview, Dominguez talks about her experience growing up in Bushwick and how she was often perceived as Latina and not Ecuadorian. She talks about her relationship with her family and getting in touch with her Ecuadorian roots, where she moved to teach.
